ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a whole lot about a wide range of subjects through the journalism articles we read each week

I learned how to write in a journalistic style I wasn't previously very familiar with. I think Professor Surowiecki did a great job with the syllabus and assigned readings from a range of journalists/authors.

This is really a learning by reading course. The selected readings are fantastic and the way to actually get something meaningful from the course is to do them and study them closely. I think I learned most of all that anything can qualify as the Journalism of Ideas, or more broadly as something an audience wants to read, if you have the right frame of mind when writing it. And I found that thought immensely comforting.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Fun assignments and readings but very disorganized, nonsensical feedback (if you can get any), unclear expectations

Strengths: the readings for each week were phenomenally interesting and the writing prompts were awesome. Weaknesses: class time is devoted to summarizing and discussing the ideas in the articles as opposed to talking about the writing techniques used to present the information which made it more difficult when it came time to write our own journalism pieces because we were simply expected to learn how to write journalism via osmosis.
It was not a super organized class. The readings were all interesting but there was no structure to them; every class felt kind of like a one off seminar.

The stength again, is the selected readings, which are diverse, almost always politically forward, and thoroughly engaging. On top of that, the way Professor Suroweicki manages the open forum style of class leaves room for ideas to be fully fleshed out in discussion, not just for everyone to give a hollow preprepared comment on each of the themes of the piece.

I think the weakness is that the guidance on the papers was not very present, and sometimes the discussion could turn into meandering confusion. However, these far from outweigh the pros, and are likely an unavoidable side-effect of a course approached with Suroweicki's mindset, which is a valuable one.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, the readings for this class were always a highlight of my week and I learned so much about a wide range of topics. The grading on the essays is pretty hard (though fair)
I would recommend this class to another student, especially someone potentially interested in pursuing journalism. Professor Surowiecki has really great insight and writing tips!

I would recommend this course to any student that both wants to be a writer and feels at a loss with that to do with that talent in an increasingly horrifying world. The course showed me that as long as I continue to stay in tune with the world around me, I can make writing a career and use that as a skill that uplifts that world. Also, it was just a lot fun!
